Dozens of members of Congress and Senators have called on the Biden administration to support a new issuance of SDRs without delay and demonstrate global leadership in the face of these challenges. 

The need is more urgent than ever.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-07-12/us-democrats-urge-new-650-billion-imf-aid-on-ukraine-war-hit

The U.S. has considerable influence at the IMF. 

The Biden administration can support a new issuance of SDRs at the IMF without prior approval from Congress can make the difference for billions of people ‚Äî and it won‚Äôt cost American taxpayers a penny.

Progressives in Congress ‚Äî led by @RepJayapal, @SenWarren, and @RepChuyGarcia ‚Äî economists, civil society groups and humanitarian aid organizations have all urged the Biden administration to immediately support a new issuance of SDRs.

https://progressives.house.gov/press-releases?ContentRecord_id=1B3E836D-7DE4-45F6-97BA-EC4589B71CE3

The situation today is even more threatening than the start of the pandemic for developing countries, with a crisis in food, energy and finance threatening as many as 1.7 billion people.

But SDRs can only help if they are made available.

Ukraine has already used up their entire last year‚Äôs issuance of SDRs from last year.

A new issuance would provide Ukraine a $2.75 billion lifeline to combat the massive economic damage caused by the war.

Within the first six months of the IMF‚Äôs issuance last year, at least 99 developing countries used their SDRs, with at least 40% going to Covid-related priorities like vaccines. These were especially crucial in Sub-Saharan Africa.

Only 21% of people in low-income countries have received at least one dose of the vaccine. 63% of global COVID deaths came from low- and middle-income countries. 

But 62 developing countries spent more paying off external debt in 2020 than on health care.

The IMF issued SDRs last year, but there is clear need for more.

276 million people are at risk of starvation. Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine has disrupted the global food supply, increasing developing countries' need for funding that can stave off life-threatening hunger.

SDRs are one of the best forms of economic support, far more effective than direct aid or loans. SDRs can be used right away and don‚Äôt have to be paid back.

The African Union, which represents 50+ lower-income nations, has been pushing the IMF for new allocation of SDRs.

SDRs are international reserve assets, which the IMF can create for its 189 member countries.

They help developing countries protect themselves against financial crises, and can be exchanged to pay for health needs, pay off debts, and purchase food, medicine, and more.

August 19 is World Humanitarian Day, established by the U.N. to advocate for the survival, well-being and dignity of people affected by crises.
